KeywordList: Economic costs and social benefits of emission reduction

Article.ArticleTitle: Current investigations on global N<sub>2</sub>O emissions and reductions: Prospect and outlook.

AbstractText: Global nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O) emissions merit scrutiny, because N<sub>2</sub>O is the third most important greenhouse gas for global warming and the predominant ozone-depleting substance in this century. Here we recapitulate global natural and anthropogenic N<sub>2</sub>O sources, comprehensively depict global sectoral human-induced N<sub>2</sub>O emissions by country, thoroughly survey all existing approaches for mitigating human-induced N<sub>2</sub>O emissions, preview the economic costs and social benefits from abating N<sub>2</sub>O emissions, and summarize roadblocks for achieving its emission reductions. From 1970 to 2018, the annual global anthropogenic N<sub>2</sub>O emissions increased by 64%-about 3.6 teragrams (Tg); agricultural sources primarily accounted for 78% of this increment. We find the social benefits from reducing N<sub>2</sub>O emissions override the economic costs for abatements, only except precision farming for agricultural sources and replacement by Xe for anesthetic, thus justifying the motivation for crafting policies to limit its emissions. Net zero N<sub>2</sub>O emissions cannot be achieved via applying current technologies and breeding N<sub>2</sub>O-reducing microbes is a potential method to accrue N<sub>2</sub>O sinks.
